title: Tommy O'Donnell
text:
Tommy O'Donnell (born 21 May 1987) is an <a href="Irish%20people">Irish</a> former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player, who spent his entire career with his native province of <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a>, whilst also earning 13 international caps for <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland</a>. O'Donnell played primarily as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Flanker">flanker</a> and represented <a href="UL%20Bohemians%20R.F.C.">UL Bohemians</a> in the <a href="All-Ireland%20League%20%28rugby%20union%29">All-Ireland League</a>.
Early life.
O'Donnell began playing rugby for <a href="Clanwilliam%20Rugby%20Club">Clanwilliam</a> at an underage level, before progressing to senior level. He also played for East Munster and Irish Youths whilst at Clanwilliam.
Munster.
O'Donnell made his Munster debut against <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a> on 22 September 2007, during a <a href="United%20Rugby%20Championship">Magners League</a> fixture. He was part of the historic Munster team that beat <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> 15–6 at <a href="Thomond%20Park">Thomond Park</a> on 16 November 2010. He made his <a href="European%20Rugby%20Champions%20Cup">Heineken Cup</a> debut off the bench during Munster's 19–13 victory against Scarlets on 18 December 2011.
He signed a new two-year contract with Munster in March 2012. O'Donnell made his first Heineken Cup start in the quarter-final against Ulster on 8 April 2012. He was named Munster Player of the Year for the 2012–13 season, following in the footsteps of teammates <a href="Donnacha%20Ryan">Donnacha Ryan</a>, <a href="James%20Coughlan">James Coughlan</a>, <a href="Mick%20O%27Driscoll">Mick O'Driscoll</a>, <a href="David%20Wallace%20%28rugby%20union%29">David Wallace</a>, <a href="John%20Hayes%20%28rugby%20union%29">John Hayes</a> and <a href="Ronan%20O%27Gara">Ronan O'Gara</a>. O'Donnell signed a new contract with Munster in November 2013 which will see him remain with the province until June 2016. He made his return from a knee injury sustained in September 2013 for Munster A on 6 December 2013.
He was nominated for the 2015 Munster Rugby Senior Player of the Year Award in April 2015. O'Donnell won his 100th cap for Munster on 25 April 2015, scoring a try in the 30–19 win against <a href="Benetton%20Rugby">Benetton</a> and winning the Man-of-the-Match award. He was named in the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20Pro12">2014–15 Pro12</a> Dream Team, alongside teammate <a href="CJ%20Stander">CJ Stander</a>. In December 2015, O'Donnell signed a three-year contract with Munster. On 27 December 2015, O'Donnell made his return from the injury he sustained during the World Cup with Ireland, coming off the bench against <a href="Leinster%20Rugby">Leinster</a> during a <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Pro12">2015–16 Pro12</a> game.
On 3 September 2016, O'Donnell won the Man-of-the-Match award in Munster's win against <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a> in the opening round of the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Pro12">2016–17 Pro12</a>. On 11 November 2016, O'Donnell captained Munster for the first time and led them to a historic 27–14 win against the <a href="M%C4%81ori%20All%20Blacks">Māori All Blacks</a>. O'Donnell won his 150th cap for Munster on 21 October 2017, doing so in the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20European%20Rugby%20Champions%20Cup">2017–18 European Rugby Champions Cup</a> fixture against <a href="Racing%2092">Racing 92</a>. O'Donnell made his return from a shoulder injury sustained in early November 2017 on 8 December 2017, playing the full 80 minutes for <a href="Munster%20Rugby%23Munster%20A">Munster A</a> in their <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20British%20and%20Irish%20Cup">2017–18 British and Irish Cup</a> defeat at the hands of <a href="Bedford%20Blues">Bedford Blues</a>. However, O'Donnell suffered a recurrence of the shoulder injury during Munster's <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Pro14">2017–18 Pro14</a> round 18 win against <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a> which subsequently required surgery, ruling him out for the remainder of the 2017–18 season.
He scored two tries in Munster's 64–7 win against <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a> in round 5 of the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Pro14">2018–19 Pro14</a> on 29 September 2018. O'Donnell signed a two-year contract extension with Munster in October 2018, a deal that will see him remain with the province until at least June 2021. He suffered an ankle injury during Munster's <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20European%20Rugby%20Champions%20Cup%20pool%20stage%23Pool%202">Champions Cup</a> win against <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a> on 20 October 2018; he returned from the injury during Munster's fixture against <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a> on 21 December 2018.
After 14 seasons with the province, O'Donnell retired at the end of the 2020–21 season. His final appearance for the province was in their 31–27 win against <a href="Cardiff%20Rugby">Cardiff Blues</a> in round 4 of the <a href="Pro14%20Rainbow%20Cup">Pro14 Rainbow Cup</a> on 28 May 2021.
Ireland.
O'Donnell has been capped for Ireland at U-18 and U-20 grades. He was part of the U-20 <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28rugby%20union%29">Grand Slam</a> winning team in 2007. He received his first senior call-up on 21 January 2013, when he was drafted into Ireland's <a href="2013%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2013 Six Nations Championship</a> training squad. O'Donnell made his debut for <a href="Ireland%20Wolfhounds">Ireland Wolfhounds</a> on 25 January 2013, starting in the friendly against <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a>. He was added to Ireland's Six Nations squad for the fixture against <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> on 18 February 2013.
O'Donnell was named in the Ireland squad for the <a href="2013%20mid-year%20rugby%20test%20series">2013 Ireland tour to North America</a> on 19 May 2013. He made his debut for the senior Ireland team on 8 June 2013, coming on as a replacement against the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">United States</a>. O'Donnell made his first start for Ireland against <a href="Canada%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Canada</a> on 15 June 2013, also scoring his first try for Ireland in the game.
O'Donnell started for <a href="Ireland%20Wolfhounds">Ireland Wolfhounds</a> in their friendly against <a href="England%20Saxons">England Saxons</a> on 25 January 2014. On 27 January 2014, O'Donnell was named in Ireland's 34-man squad for the opening two fixtures of the <a href="2014%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2014 Six Nations Championship</a>. He came off the bench against <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> on 2 February 2014. O'Donnell came off the bench against <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> on 8 February 2014. O'Donnell was selected in the <a href="Emerging%20Ireland">Emerging Ireland</a> squad on 26 May 2014. He started against <a href="Russia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Russia</a> in their first <a href="2014%20IRB%20Nations%20Cup">2014 IRB Nations Cup</a> match on 13 June 2014, scoring a try. O'Donnell started in their second game against <a href="Uruguay%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Uruguay</a> on 18 June 2014. He came off the bench in the 31–10 win <a href="Romania%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Romania</a> on 22 June 2014, a win that secured the <a href="2014%20IRB%20Nations%20Cup">2014 IRB Nations Cup</a> for Emerging Ireland.
O'Donnell was named in the Ireland squad for the <a href="2014%20end-of-year%20rugby%20union%20internationals">2014 November Tests</a> on 21 October 2014. He came off the bench during the 29–15 win against <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a> on 8 November 2014. O'Donnell started in the 49–7 win against <a href="Georgia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Georgia</a> on 16 November 2014.
He was named in the Ireland squad for the opening rounds of the <a href="2015%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2015 Six Nations Championship</a> on 1 February 2015. He started against <a href="Italy%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy</a> on 7 February 2015, scoring a try in Ireland's 26–3 win. He came off the bench in the 19–9 win against <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> on 1 March 2015. England's failure to score enough points against France meant Ireland won the 2015 Six Nations Championship, the first time Ireland had won back-to-back championships since 1948–49.
O'Donnell was named in the 45-man training squad for the <a href="2015%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2015 Rugby World Cup</a> on 24 June 2015. He started in the first World Cup warm-up against Wales on 8 August 2015, but went off injured in the second half. On 10 August 2015, it was confirmed that O'Donnell had dislocated his hip, requiring a minimum of 6 weeks non-weight bearing activity, ruling him out of the 2015 Rugby World Cup.
On 20 January 2016, O'Donnell was named in Ireland's 35-man squad for the <a href="2016%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2016 Six Nations Championship</a>. On 7 February 2016, O'Donnell started against Wales in Ireland's opening match of the Six Nations. On 13 February 2016, O'Donnell came off the bench against France to replace <a href="Se%C3%A1n%20O%27Brien%20%28rugby%20union%2C%20born%201987%29">Seán O'Brien</a> after he went off injured. On 23 January 2017, O'Donnell was named in the Ireland squad for the opening two rounds of the <a href="2017%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2017 Six Nations Championship</a>. O'Donnell was also selected in the squad for the <a href="2017%20mid-year%20rugby%20union%20internationals">2017 Summer Tour</a> against the <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">United States</a> and <a href="Japan%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Japan</a>. However, an ankle injury ruled O'Donnell out of the tour.
Statistics.
International analysis by opposition.
Correct as of 10 August 2019
Personal life.
On 24 June 2016, O'Donnell married Elisse O'Grady in <a href="Kenmare">Kenmare</a>, <a href="County%20Kerry">County Kerry</a>.
